"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2015-10-12 12:41:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/548f54d7069fd57046bca9f8e9d3dc34a2c2264b', 'message': "Add composite namevar for tenant, user, user_role.

There are two sides on this patch, the user facing one, and the
developer's one.

It gives more flexibility for the interface used by the user for the
Keystone_tenant, Keystone_user and Keystone_user_roles resources.  For
instance to specify a user and give the admin role, currently you have
to:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin::admin_domain':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin::admin_domain@openstackv3::admin_domain':
    ensure         => present,
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

Now you can specify it like this:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    domain      => 'admin_domain',
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin@openstackv3':
    ensure         => present,
    user_domain    => 'admin_domain',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

For the developer this simplify the code.  Puppet is using composite
namevar to make all the resources unique.  So guessing what pattern is
used in the title is no longer required.  For instance this :

  keystone_tenant { 'project_one': ensure => present }
  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'Default', ensure => present }

is detected as the same tenant by puppet.

The same is true for dependencies. This is working correctly:

keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'domain_one', ensure => present }
file {'/tmp/toto': ensure => present, require => Keystone_tenant['project_one::domain_one'] }

Change-Id: I4deb27dc6f71fb7a7ec6a9c72bd0e1412c2e9a30

"}, {'number': 26, 'created': '2015-10-14 22:06:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/4a742a87698822a1dffb9f9c029c931cf4078e84', 'message': "Add composite namevar for tenant, user, user_role.

There are two sides on this patch, the user facing one, and the
developer's one.

It gives more flexibility for the interface used by the user for the
Keystone_tenant, Keystone_user and Keystone_user_roles resources.  For
instance to specify a user and give the admin role, currently you have
to:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin::admin_domain':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin::admin_domain@openstackv3::admin_domain':
    ensure         => present,
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

Now you can specify it like this:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    domain      => 'admin_domain',
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin@openstackv3':
    ensure         => present,
    user_domain    => 'admin_domain',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

For the developer this simplify the code.  Puppet is using composite
namevar to make all the resources unique.  So guessing what pattern is
used in the title is no longer required.  For instance this :

  keystone_tenant { 'project_one': ensure => present }
  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'Default', ensure => present }

keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'domain_one', ensure => present }
file {'/tmp/toto': ensure => present, require => Keystone_tenant['project_one::domain_one'] }

In autorequire term in type definition, you just have to pass the fully
qualified name (with the domain suffix for user and tenant) of the
resource and puppet will do the matching, whatever the original title
is.  See the examples in user and tenant in keystone_user_role type.

    domain      => 'admin_domain',
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin@openstackv3':
    ensure         => present,
    user_domain    => 'admin_domain',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

For the developer this simplify the code.  Puppet is using composite
namevar to make all the resources unique.  So guessing what pattern is
used in the title is no longer required.  For instance this :

  keystone_tenant { 'project_one': ensure => present }
  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'Default', ensure => present }

is detected as the same tenant by puppet.

The same is true for dependencies. This is working correctly:

keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'domain_one', ensure => present }
file {'/tmp/toto': ensure => present, require => Keystone_tenant['project_one::domain_one'] }

In autorequire term in type definition, you just have to pass the fully
qualified name (with the domain suffix for user and tenant) of the
resource and puppet will do the matching, whatever the original title
is.  See the examples in user and tenant in keystone_user_role type.

Change-Id: I4deb27dc6f71fb7a7ec6a9c72bd0e1412c2e9a30

There are two sides on this patch, the user facing one, and the
developer's one.

It gives more flexibility for the interface used by the user for the
Keystone_tenant, Keystone_user and Keystone_user_roles resources.  For
instance to specify a user and give the admin role, currently you have
to:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin::admin_domain':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin::admin_domain@openstackv3::admin_domain':
    ensure         => present,
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

Now you can specify it like this:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    domain      => 'admin_domain',
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin@openstackv3':
    ensure         => present,
    user_domain    => 'admin_domain',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

For the developer this simplify the code.  Puppet is using composite
namevar to make all the resources unique.  So guessing what pattern is
used in the title is no longer required.  For instance this :

  keystone_tenant { 'project_one': ensure => present }
  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'Default', ensure => present }

is detected as the same tenant by puppet.

The same is true for dependencies. This is working correctly:

  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'domain_one', ensure => present }
  file {'/tmp/needed': ensure => present, require => Keystone_tenant['project_one::domain_one'] }

In autorequire term in type definition, you just have to pass the fully
qualified name (with the domain suffix for user and tenant) of the
resource and puppet will do the matching, whatever the original title
is.  See the examples in user and tenant in keystone_user_role type.

Change-Id: I4deb27dc6f71fb7a7ec6a9c72bd0e1412c2e9a30

commit_message:
Add composite namevar for tenant, user, user_role.

There are two sides on this patch, the user facing one, and the
developer's one.

It gives more flexibility for the interface used by the user for the
Keystone_tenant, Keystone_user and Keystone_user_roles resources.  For
instance to specify a user and give the admin role, currently you have
to:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin::admin_domain':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin::admin_domain@openstackv3::admin_domain':
    ensure         => present,
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

Now you can specify it like this:

  keystone_user { 'new_admin':
    ensure      => present,
    enabled     => true,
    domain      => 'admin_domain',
    tenant      => 'openstackv3::admin_domain',
    email       => 'test@example.tld',
    password    => 'a_big_secret',
  }
  keystone_user_role { 'new_admin@openstackv3':
    ensure         => present,
    user_domain    => 'admin_domain',
    project_domain => 'admin_domain',
    roles          => ['admin'],
  }

For the developer this simplify the code.  Puppet is using composite
namevar to make all the resources unique.  So guessing what pattern is
used in the title is no longer required.  For instance this :

  keystone_tenant { 'project_one': ensure => present }
  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'Default', ensure => present }

is detected as the same tenant by puppet.

The same is true for dependencies. This is working correctly:

  keystone_tenant { 'meaningless': name => 'project_one', domain => 'domain_one', ensure => present }
  file {'/tmp/needed': ensure => present, require => Keystone_tenant['project_one::domain_one'] }

In autorequire term in type definition, you just have to pass the fully
qualified name (with the domain suffix for user and tenant) of the
resource and puppet will do the matching, whatever the original title
is.  See the examples in user and tenant in keystone_user_role type.

Change-Id: I4deb27dc6f71fb7a7ec6a9c72bd0e1412c2e9a30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/19/226919/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: newparam(:domain) do isnamevar def self.title_patterns [ [ /^(.+)::(.+)$/, [ [:name], [:domain] ] ], [ /^(.+)$/, [ [:name] ] ] ] end
deleted_lines: newproperty(:domain) do newvalues(nil, /\S+/) def insync?(is) raise(Puppet::Error, "[keystone_tenant]: The domain cannot be changed from #{self.should} to #{is}") unless self.should == is true end

added_lines: #!/bin/bash} clean_exit () {cat ${GNOCCHI_DATA}/api-paste.ini <<EOF [pipeline:main] pipeline = gnocchi [app:gnocchi] paste.app_factory = gnocchi.rest.app:app_factory EOF gnocchi-dbsync --config-file ${GNOCCHI_DATA}/gnocchi.conf

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2015-05-13 16:15:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/c9b8ce5f8a888674af894f2ccecdd6c36d445a5a', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api - the endpoint resource

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:
1) Implements support for the keystone_endpoint resource using
the v3 api.  With v3, endpoint create does not take all 3 of the
admin, internal, and public endpoints.  Instead, it takes 1 at a
time.  This implementation will call endpoint create and endpoint
delete 3 times to create or delete all 3 endpoints with 1 call
to the keystone_endpoint resource in manifests, in order not to
break the existing manifest API.  For modify/set, it will use
the ID of each endpoint.  It keeps the 3 IDs in a comma
delimited list.

Change-Id: I8c21b21803805919ae7981ffef74c5e205afe1c1
Co-Authored-By: Gilles Dubreuil <gilles@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emacchi@redhat.com>
'}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2015-05-13 19:44:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/fcc61194295f8abf5ded1a7bbf0bba48cbdc2a36', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api - the endpoint resource

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:
1) Implements support for the keystone_endpoint resource using
the v3 api.  With v3, endpoint create does not take all 3 of the
admin, internal, and public endpoints.  Instead, it takes 1 at a
time.  This implementation will call endpoint create and endpoint
delete 3 times to create or delete all 3 endpoints with 1 call
to the keystone_endpoint resource in manifests, in order not to
break the existing manifest API.  For modify/set, it will use
the ID of each endpoint.  It keeps the 3 IDs in a comma
delimited list.

Change-Id: I8c21b21803805919ae7981ffef74c5e205afe1c1
Co-Authored-By: Gilles Dubreuil <gilles@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emacchi@redhat.com>
'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2015-06-04 18:15:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/fc0ac1c86d5df945d2d5b448d1cf08755716c984', 'message': 'support for keystone v3 api - the endpoint resource

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
This patch implements these parts of the blueprint:
1) Implements support for the keystone_endpoint resource using
the v3 api.  With v3, endpoint create does not take all 3 of the
admin, internal, and public endpoints.  Instead, it takes 1 at a
time.  This implementation will call endpoint create and endpoint
delete 3 times to create or delete all 3 endpoints with 1 call
to the keystone_endpoint resource in manifests, in order not to
break the existing manifest API.  For modify/set, it will use
the ID of each endpoint.  It keeps the 3 IDs in a comma
delimited list.

Change-Id: I8c21b21803805919ae7981ffef74c5e205afe1c1
Co-Authored-By: Gilles Dubreuil <gilles@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emacchi@redhat.com>
'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-06-05 10:51:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/90a17fd6625f52086836fcfa724294de0321d336', 'message': "keystone_endpoint resource using API version 3

Implements support for the keystone_endpoint resource using
the v3 api.
In keystone v3 there is one endpoint per 'interface' (url)
To offer backward compatiblity for this provider API it creates a 'virtual'
endpoint by combo of the 3 URLs (admin, internal, private) by keeping the 3 IDs
in a comma delimited list.

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
Co-Authored-By: Gilles Dubreuil <gilles@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Emilien Macchi <emacchi@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8c21b21803805919ae7981ffef74c5e205afe1c1

commit_message:
keystone_endpoint provider for Keystone v3 api

In keystone v3 there is one endpoint per 'interface' (url).
To offer backward compatibility this provider creates a 'virtual' endpoint by
combining the 3 URLs (admin, internal, private) using their 3 IDs in a comma
delimited list.

Implements: blueprint api-v3-support
Change-Id: I8c21b21803805919ae7981ffef74c5e205afe1c1

commit_message:
Add support for Xen PV disks

Xen paravirtualised disks (supported by most modern kernels) have the
"xvd" prefix (e.g. xvda0).  The functions to strip partitions need to
match on Xen PV disks otherwise the device name is discarded.

Change-Id: I5539d2afba3fae30d1ddb49dcbf077113d38bbf7
Closes-Bug: #1498576

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-aodh refs/changes/09/237709/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' # LP1492636 - Cohabitation of compile matcher and webmock WebMock.disable_net_connect!(:allow => "169.254.169.254") describe 'aodh::listener' do let :pre_condition do "class { '::aodh': }" end shared_examples_for 'aodh-listener' do context 'when enabled' do it { is_expected.to contain_class('aodh::params') } it 'installs aodh-listener package' do is_expected.to contain_package(platform_params[:listener_package_name]).with( :ensure => 'present' ) end it 'configures aodh-listener service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-listener').with( :ensure => 'running', :name => platform_params[:listener_service_name], :enable => true, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end context 'when disabled' do let :params do { :enabled => false } end # Catalog compilation does not crash for lack of aodh::db it { is_expected.to compile } it 'configures aodh-listener service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-listener').with( :ensure => 'stopped', :name => platform_params[:listener_service_name], :enable => false, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end context 'when service management is disabled' do let :params do { :enabled => false, :manage_service => false } end it 'configures aodh-listener service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-listener').with( :ensure => nil, :name => platform_params[:listener_service_name], :enable => false, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end end context 'on Debian platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'Debian' } end let :platform_params do { :listener_package_name => 'aodh-listener', :listener_service_name => 'aodh-listener' } end it_configures 'aodh-listener' end context 'on RedHat platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } end let :platform_params do { :listener_package_name => 'openstack-aodh-listener', :listener_service_name => 'openstack-aodh-listener' } end it_configures 'aodh-listener' end end

Updated ansible version

This updates ansible to the latest stable release.

Change-Id: I656aeca46611ce2c0ca3d9767de9714dedb9ba6d
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-10-02 16:36:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/903ff87bbd02a3a003f468353805061adb807fa8', 'message': 'Test patch fipnamespace delete rpc [NOT FOR REVIEW]

Closes-Bug: #1501873
Change-Id: I86869f66d4afffad7db09942578b1a456a9bd418
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2015-10-02 16:57:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/cdfee8e8423f90831ee1908490bbf87aa2ed4463', 'message': 'Delete fipnamespace when external net removed on DVR

The fipnamespace is associated with an external network
on a given node. In the case of DVR there is just one
single FIP namespace for a given node. 

We have seen some race conditions in the agent for creation
and deletion of the fip namespace. See the bug report for
details on the failure.

So in order to address this race condition and make the
code more stable, we will be cleaning up the fip namespace
only when an external network is removed.

The server will be sending a rpc notification message to 
the agent to cleanup the fip namespace when the external
net is removed.

This patch address the above mentioned issue by not constantly
deleting and creating the fip namespace.

Closes-Bug: #1501873
Change-Id: I86869f66d4afffad7db09942578b1a456a9bd418

commit_message:
Delete fipnamespace when external net removed on DVR

The fipnamespace is associated with an external network
on a given node. In the case of DVR there is just one
single FIP namespace for a given node.

We have seen some race conditions in the agent for creation
and deletion of the fip namespace. See the bug report for
details on the failure.

So in order to address this race condition and make the
code more stable, we will be cleaning up the fip namespace
only when an external network is removed.

The server will be sending a rpc notification message to
the agent to cleanup the fip namespace when the external
net is removed.

This patch address the above mentioned issue by not constantly
deleting and creating the fip namespace.

Closes-Bug: #1501873
Change-Id: I86869f66d4afffad7db09942578b1a456a9bd418
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/79/230079/32 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def fip_delete_ext_net(self, context, payload): """Delete fip namespace after external network removed.""" ext_net_id = payload['ext_net_id'] fip_ns = self._fip_namespaces.get(ext_net_id) if fip_ns and not fip_ns.destroyed: self.fip_ns.cleanup_fip_namespace() LOG.debug("DVR: FIP Namespace destroyed for external_net: ", "%s", ext_net_id) self.fip_ns = None

commit_message:
add pip cache warming to non dib builder

We also need to warm the cache where we don't use disk image builder,
this copies the method to the old way of doing things as well. It's a
bit denormalized because it's not entirely clear if there is access to
all the elements when run in this mode.

Change-Id: Ie07d0fb7946a066a37c3d29c29a6e7e4d247399f

commit_message:
Correct ironic auth settings

The existing ironic.conf uses an unversioned keystone auth_url
setting. As the keystone API now defaults to v3 this can
cause provisioning failures if Ironic needs to communicate
with other services (neutron). This is because we haven't yet
updated TripleO to properly support configuration with
keystone V3.

We also need to set the ironic neutron_url because
if we don't puppet-ironic will use the auth_protocol and
auth_host parameters to construct it incorrectly if
we don't (since we no longer set those parameters).

Change-Id: Ief7fc3dbbd8b8c33ea3ec7bd127231698af27a7f
Depends-On: Ibcc63d82b6e7b9de6ef12209a43f39a4cdecb5a2
Closes-bug: #1495090

Change-Id: I4f75c7182a04903bd89aced654338d0fd2f2ba4d

commit_message:
Add virt-driver CPU thread pinning

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/virt-driver-cpu-pinning

Resubmit the thread policy aspect of the 'virt-driver-cpu-pinning'
spec, which was not implemented in Kilo.

This is a reproposal of a spec approved for Liberty. However, it
includes new naming for one of the four policies.

Change-Id: I4f75c7182a04903bd89aced654338d0fd2f2ba4d
Blueprint: virt-driver-cpu-pinning
Previously-Approved: Liberty
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/55/241355/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Virt driver pinning guest vCPU threads policies =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/virt-driver-cpu-thread-pinning This feature aims to implement the remaining functionality of the virt-driver-cpu-pinning spec. This entails implementing support for thread policies. Problem description =================== Some applications must exhibit real-time or near real-time behavior. This is general possible by making use of processor affinity and binding vCPUs to pCPUs. This functionality currently exist in Nova. However, it is also necessary to consider thread affinity in the context of simultaneous multithreading (SMT) enabled systems. In these systems, competition for shared resources can result in unpredictable behavior. Use Cases ---------- Depending on the workload being executed the end user or cloud admin may wish to have control over how the guest used hyperthreads. To maximise cache efficiency, the guest may wish to be pinned to thread siblings. Conversely the guest may wish to avoid thread siblings (i.e. only pin to one sibling) or even avoid hosts with threads entirely. This level of control is of particular importance to Network Function Virtualization (NFV) deployments, which care about maximizing cache efficiency of vCPUs. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== The flavor extra specs will be enhanced to support one new parameter: * hw:cpu_threads_policy=avoid|separate|isolate|require This policy is an extension to the already implemented CPU policy parameter: * hw:cpu_policy=shared|dedicated The threads policy will control how the scheduler / virt driver places guests with respect to CPU threads. It will only apply if the scheduler policy is 'dedicated' - avoid: the scheduler will not place the guest on a host which has hyperthreads. - separate: if the host has threads, each vCPU will be placed on a different core. ie no two vCPUs will be placed on thread siblings - isolate: if the host has threads, each vCPU will be placed on a different core and no vCPUs from other guests will be able to be placed on the same core. ie one thread sibling is guaranteed to always be unused, - require: if the host has threads, vCPU will be placed on the same core, so they are thread siblings. The image metadata properties will also allow specification of the threads policy: * hw_cpu_threads_policy=avoid|separate|isolate|require This will only be honored if the flavor does not already have a threads policy set. This ensures the cloud administrator can have absolute control over threads policy if desired. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. The necessary changes were already completed in the original spec. REST API impact --------------- No impact. The existing APIs already support arbitrary data in the flavor extra specs. Security impact --------------- No impact. Notifications impact -------------------- No impact. The notifications system is not used by this change. Other end user impact --------------------- No impact. Support for flavor extra specs is already available in the Python clients. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Support for CPU policies already exists and this is merely an extension of that functionality. Other deployer impact --------------------- The cloud administrator will gain the ability to define flavors with explicit threading policy. Although not required by this design, it is expected that the administrator will commonly use the same host aggregates to group hosts for both CPU pinning and large page usage, since these concepts are complementary and expected to be used together. This will minimize the administrative burden of configuring host aggregates. Developer impact ---------------- It is expected that most hypervisors will have the ability to support the required thread policies. The flavor parameter is simple enough that any Nova driver would be able to support it. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sfinucan Work Items ---------- * Enhance the scheduler to take account of threads policy when choosing which host to place the guest on. * Enhance the scheduler to take account of threads policy when mapping vCPUs to pCPUs Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= It is not practical to test this feature using the gate and tempest at this time, since effective testing will require that the guests running the test be provided with multiple NUMA nodes, each in turn with multiple CPUs. These features will be validated using a third-party CI (Intel Compute CI). Documentation Impact ==================== None. The documentation changes were made in the previous change. References ========== Current "big picture" research and design for the topic of CPU and memory resource utilization and placement. vCPU topology is a subset of this work: * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VirtDriverGuestCPUMemoryPlacement Current CPU pinning validation tests for Intel Compute CI: * https://github.com/stackforge/intel-nfv-ci-tests Existing CPU Pinning spec: * http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/kilo/implemented/virt-driver-cpu-pinning.html History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced

added_lines: from designateclient.v2 import utils as v2_utils def get(self, tld): tld = v2_utils.resolve_by_name(self.list, tld) return self._get('/tlds/%s' % tld) def update(self, tld, values): tld = v2_utils.resolve_by_name(self.list, tld) return self._patch('/tlds/%s' % tld, data=values) def delete(self, tld): tld = v2_utils.resolve_by_name(self.list, tld) return self._delete('/tlds/%s' % tld)
deleted_lines: def get(self, tld_id): url = '/tlds/%s' % tld_id return self._get(url) def update(self, tld_id, values): url = '/tlds/%s' % tld_id return self._patch(url, data=values) def delete(self, tld_id): url = '/tlds/%s' % tld_id return self._delete(url)

commit_message:
Use assertTrue/False instead of assertEqual(T/F)

Usage of assertEqual(True/False, ***) should be changed to a more
meaningful format of assertTrue/False(***).

Change-Id: I8623f5534f00ea1690f74a297488957a8d35f074
Closes-Bug: #1510001

commit_message:
Implement Notifier service

* Manifest
* Unit tests
* Acceptance tests
* Example manifest

Change-Id: Ib0b82245fa9ffeb2c23bd26e2e7f3db6a0b6fe41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-aodh refs/changes/08/237708/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' # LP1492636 - Cohabitation of compile matcher and webmock WebMock.disable_net_connect!(:allow => "169.254.169.254") describe 'aodh::notifier' do let :pre_condition do "class { '::aodh': }" end shared_examples_for 'aodh-notifier' do context 'when enabled' do it { is_expected.to contain_class('aodh::params') } it 'installs aodh-notifier package' do is_expected.to contain_package(platform_params[:notifier_package_name]).with( :ensure => 'present' ) end it 'configures aodh-notifier service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-notifier').with( :ensure => 'running', :name => platform_params[:notifier_service_name], :enable => true, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end context 'when disabled' do let :params do { :enabled => false } end # Catalog compilation does not crash for lack of aodh::db it { is_expected.to compile } it 'configures aodh-notifier service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-notifier').with( :ensure => 'stopped', :name => platform_params[:notifier_service_name], :enable => false, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end context 'when service management is disabled' do let :params do { :enabled => false, :manage_service => false } end it 'configures aodh-notifier service' do is_expected.to contain_service('aodh-notifier').with( :ensure => nil, :name => platform_params[:notifier_service_name], :enable => false, :hasstatus => true, :hasrestart => true, :tag => 'aodh-service', ) end end end context 'on Debian platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'Debian' } end let :platform_params do { :notifier_package_name => 'aodh-notifier', :notifier_service_name => 'aodh-notifier' } end it_configures 'aodh-notifier' end context 'on RedHat platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } end let :platform_params do { :notifier_package_name => 'openstack-aodh-notifier', :notifier_service_name => 'openstack-aodh-notifier' } end it_configures 'aodh-notifier' end end

commit_message:
Implement Evaluator service

* Manifest for evaluator and auth
* acceptance
* example
* unit tests
* Fix dbsync command and run it to make evaluator work

Change-Id: I3e9f43ebeceaf62abed9412959c067c4bd4409da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-aodh refs/changes/62/237662/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Installs the aodh evaluator service # # == Params # [*enabled*] # (optional) Should the service be enabled. # Defaults to true. # # [*manage_service*] # (optional) Whether the service should be managed by Puppet. # Defaults to true. # # [*package_ensure*] # (optional) ensure state for package. # Defaults to 'present' # # [*coordination_url*] # (optional) The url to use for distributed group membership coordination. # Defaults to undef. # class aodh::evaluator ( $manage_service = true, $enabled = true, $package_ensure = 'present', $coordination_url = undef, ) { include ::aodh::params Aodh_config<||> ~> Service['aodh-evaluator'] if $coordination_url { aodh_config { 'coordination/backend_url' : value => $coordination_url; } } Package[$::aodh::params::evaluator_package_name] -> Service['aodh-evaluator'] ensure_resource( 'package', [$::aodh::params::evaluator_package_name], { ensure => $package_ensure } ) if $manage_service { if $enabled { $service_ensure = 'running' } else { $service_ensure = 'stopped' } } Package['aodh'] -> Service['aodh-evaluator'] service { 'aodh-evaluator': ensure => $service_ensure, name => $::aodh::params::evaluator_service_name, enable => $enabled, hasstatus => true, hasrestart => true } }

commit_message:
Add default stable/liberty branch to .gitreview

This patch adds the defaultbranch tag to the .gitreview file for
stable/liberty to ensure that any reviews done from this branch end up
in the right place on gerrit.

Change-Id: I55db3f427b35cdc8e27a0fd45c5b6960f8becd97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/85/237985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
PortOpt cleanups

Commit 44d73d1ad3073958c8d5cce933deedc7e6ea5f83 added support
for oslo.config 2.6.

Commit 4d2cb851b7b7d6399163ca9f624f656a3e41ac34 added this to Neutron.

The patch adds a few missing items.

Change-Id: Id36515e28458c354ddb6fe3656f182d17df08f8a

commit_message:
Support jinja2 in rally.ui.utils

Use pkgutil to get base templates path.
Move ci templates to rally.ui package.
Remove cli functionality and use rally.ui directly in CI code.

Change-Id: If88ba2ed851eb9796ef5fae84398b1c185dbab0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/07/240807/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pkgutildef get_template(template): from mako.template import Template dirs = os.path.join(pkgutil.get_loader("rally.ui").filename, "templates") lookup = mako.lookup.TemplateLookup(directories=[dirs]) return Template(filename=os.path.realpath(template), lookup=lookup)
deleted_lines: def get_template(template_path): templates_dir = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), "templates") lookup_dirs = [ templates_dir, os.path.abspath(os.path.join(templates_dir, "..", "..", "..")) ] lookup = mako.lookup.TemplateLookup(directories=lookup_dirs) try: return lookup.get_template(template_path) except mako.exceptions.TopLevelLookupException as e: raise ValueError(e)

commit_message:
Add standard status footer

One of the requests we got during Summit was to make OpenStack Health
look more like other status pages. This commit includes the status
footer.

Change-Id: I15a6776cd21ae668f231b47c89797748de03d520
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/64/241364/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #footer p a { color: #656565; text-decoration: underline; } #footer ul { margin: 10px 0px 20px; padding: 0px; list-style: none; } #footer a, #footer a:visited, #footer a:active { color: black; } #footer h3 { color: #de0000; font: 130% 'PT Sans', serif; }

subject: Provide the correct Cinder volume unit size
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-29 01:14:34.000000000', 'files': ['api-ref/src/wadls/volume-api/src/v2/os-volume-manage-v2.wadl', 'api-ref/src/wadls/volume-api/src/v2/os-vol-image-meta-v2.wadl', 'api-ref/src/wadls/volume-api/src/v2/volume-api-v2.wadl', 'api-ref/src/wadls/volume-api/src/v2/common.ent'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-site/commit/8a7f99bb0c25ed9c570096f4dbc44cd9316996bf', 'message': 'Provide the correct Cinder volume unit size

Both Horizon and the cinder client documents the size paramater in
gigabyes(GB) but the API docs(both v1 and v2) list the size units as
gibibytes(GiB). The correct unit should be gigabytes(GB).

Change-Id: I4613e40d7aa2eb53c5718b0bbce693ef30951ec6
Closes-Bug: 1511167
'}]
commit_message:
Provide the correct Cinder volume unit size

Both Horizon and the cinder client documents the size paramater in
gigabyes(GB) but the API docs(both v1 and v2) list the size units as
gibibytes(GiB). The correct unit should be gigabytes(GB).

Change-Id: I4613e40d7aa2eb53c5718b0bbce693ef30951ec6
Closes-Bug: 1511167

commit_message:
Deprecate create_tenant and tenant_name

As of Liberty, tenant_name was deprecated in favor of project_name.

:create_tenant is also being deprecated in favor of :create_project

Change-Id: I347abf1c004ea78f85024114407c8820e40c3ee7
Depends-On: I4240e875f0495c0b484b1740f08ac037528a78aa
Partial-Bug: #1512480

commit_message:
Use _assert_has_(no)_errors() in hacking tests

_assert_has_errors() and _assert_has_no_errors() us much easier to read
and understand. This change switches over the tests to use those fixture
methods.

Change-Id: I4aa8f973d1be34739a7fb2edcf85a956b2cf7859
Closes-Bug: #1512802

subject: Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-22 16:48:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/7c6d07c7ecd9eee07c70393d9bb45dc72affade0', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: Id33c964252cbd1fa1e1b2d06ae946da7fca9bcf5

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

It also stop testing nova::rabbitmq which is something we don't want
to support anymore. It's included in this commit otherwise unit tests
will fail.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Depends-On: Ifa4026fb9407cd7f43685c89ac69e60588783915
Change-Id: Id33c964252cbd1fa1e1b2d06ae946da7fca9bcf5

added_lines: gem 'r10k', :require => 'false'

commit_message:
Normalize int config values to string

We have no things that expect actual int values. It's easy to write
ints in yaml though - so normalize them to strings.

Change-Id: I58cfdda697da9b7e030f4165ef8e60f4e9d00b66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config refs/changes/25/241725/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif isinstance(value, int): new_config[key] = str(value)

subject: VPNaaS: Multiple Local Subnets feature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-01 21:55:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/commit/21017acb8d473cdcdf70884ccb92c86fb6b44094', 'message': 'VPNaaS: Multiple Local Subnets

WIP: As the migration sync functional test is failing (but manual
check of migration is working). I'm not sure I have that piece right.

Implements support for multiple local subnets for IPSec site to site
connections, using the new Endpoint Group API.

The implementation supports backwards compatibility as follows. If
a VPN service is created with a subnet, then the older API is assumed
and the user must specify the peer CIDRs for any IPSec connections
and cannot specify multiple local subnets.

If a subnet is not provided for the VPN service, then the user must
use the newer API and provide a local and peer endpoint group IDs for
the IPSec connection (and cannot specify the peer CIDRs in the IPSec
connection API).

Implication here is that the subnet will be an optional argument for
the VPN service API.

With this feature, when an endpoint group is deleted, a check is made
to ensure that there are no IPSec connections using the group.

Migration will move the subnet from VPN service API to a new endpoint
group, and specify the group in any connections using the service.
The peer CIDR(s) will be moved from each connection to an endpoint
group, with the group ID specified in the connection.

Note: As part of testing the database methods for this feature, several
more tests were created to test database access only, instead of doing
a round trip test. In a separate commit, these tests can be expanded,
and the existing round trip tests removed.

Note: Tests for building the dict used in sync requests was enhanced,
as part of supporting this feature. The previous tests didn't check
that the peer CIDR information was correct, so were enhanced as well.

Note: The service driver passes the local CIDR(s) in a new field,
called local_cidrs. This field is used for the older API, as well,
passing the subnet's CIDR, and allowing consistent consumption by the
device driver. The IP version is also passed, rather than obtaining
it from the subnet info (so both new and old API use the same fields).

Note: In the device driver, I noticed that the local CIDR's IP version
can change the config file output, so I added test cases for IPv6, as
part of enhancing the tests for multiple local CIDRs.

Note: The user could change the CIDR of a subnet that is used by a
local endpoint group. A separate commit (for Neutron) is needed to
be able to get a notification of that event. We could either force
a "sync" as a result of the change, or block the change with an in-
use exception. A decision on method will be needed for that commit.

Just for reference, these other actions are needed for this feature,
and will be done under separate commits:

- Neutron client support for API changes.
- Functional test (scenario) with new feature.
- API test for new APIs (once API tests available in repo).
- API documentation for endpoint groups and multiple subnets.
- Horizon support for feature.
- Check when changing subnet in use by endpoint group (see Note).

Change-Id: I7a011e3170d7db463a6561e550b2ead3e3311125
Partial-Bug: 1459423

and the existing round trip tests removed.

Note: Tests for building the dict used in sync requests was enhanced,
as part of supporting this feature. The previous tests didn't check
that the peer CIDR information was correct, so were enhanced as well.

Note: The service driver passes the local CIDR(s) in a new field,
called local_cidrs. This field is used for the older API, as well,
passing the subnet's CIDR, and allowing consistent consumption by the
device driver. The IP version is also passed, rather than obtaining
it from the subnet info (so both new and old API use the same fields).

Note: In the device driver, I noticed that the local CIDR's IP version
can change the config file output, so I added test cases for IPv6, as
part of enhancing the tests for multiple local CIDRs.

Note: The user could change the CIDR of a subnet that is used by a
local endpoint group. A separate commit (for Neutron) is needed to
be able to get a notification of that event. We could either force
a "sync" as a result of the change, or block the change with an in-
use exception. A decision on method will be needed for that commit.

Just for reference, these other actions are needed for this feature,
and will be done under separate commits:

- Neutron client support for API changes (review 231133).
- Functional test (scenario) with new feature.
- API test for new APIs (once API tests available in repo).
- API documentation for endpoint groups and multiple subnets.
- Horizon support for feature.
- Check when changing subnet in use by endpoint group (see Note).

Change-Id: I7a011e3170d7db463a6561e550b2ead3e3311125
Partial-Bug: 1459423

Implements support for multiple local subnets for IPSec site to site
connections, using the new Endpoint Group API.

The implementation supports backwards compatibility as follows. If
a VPN service is created with a subnet, then the older API is assumed
and the user must specify the peer CIDRs for any IPSec connections
and cannot specify multiple local subnets.

If a subnet is not provided for the VPN service, then the user must
use the newer API and provide a local and peer endpoint group IDs for
the IPSec connection (and cannot specify the peer CIDRs in the IPSec
connection API).

Implication here is that the subnet will be an optional argument for
the VPN service API.

With this feature, when an endpoint group is deleted, a check is made
to ensure that there are no IPSec connections using the group.

Migration will move the subnet from VPN service API to a new endpoint
group, and specify the group in any connections using the service.
The peer CIDR(s) will be moved from each connection to an endpoint
group, with the group ID specified in the connection.

Note: As part of testing the database methods for this feature, several
more tests were created to test database access only, instead of doing
a round trip test. In a separate commit, these tests can be expanded,
and the existing round trip tests removed.

Note: Tests for building the dict used in sync requests was enhanced,
as part of supporting this feature. The previous tests didn't check
that the peer CIDR information was correct, so were enhanced as well.

Note: The service driver passes the local CIDR(s) in a new field,
called local_cidrs. This field is used for the older API, as well,
passing the subnet's CIDR, and allowing consistent consumption by the
device driver. The IP version is also passed, rather than obtaining
it from the subnet info (so both new and old API use the same fields).

Note: In the device driver, I noticed that the local CIDR's IP version
can change the config file output, so I added test cases for IPv6, as
part of enhancing the tests for multiple local CIDRs.

Note: Created enhancement bug to improve checking, when a subnet's
CIDR is changed, and the subnet is used by VPN service or Endpoint
Group. This will require a neutron change, as well as a VPN change.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1503862

Just for reference, these other actions are needed for this feature,
and will be done under separate commits:

- Neutron client support for API changes (review 231133).
- Functional test (scenario) with new feature.
- API test for new APIs (once API tests available in repo).
- API documentation for endpoint groups and multiple subnets.
- Horizon support for feature.
- Check when changing subnet in use by endpoint group (see Note).

commit_message:
VPNaaS: Multiple Local Subnets feature

Implements support for multiple local subnets for IPSec site to site
connections, using the new Endpoint Group API.

The implementation supports backwards compatibility as follows. If
a VPN service is created with a subnet, then the older API is assumed
and the user must specify the peer CIDRs for any IPSec connections
and cannot specify multiple local subnets.

If a subnet is not provided for the VPN service, then the user must
use the newer API and provide a local and peer endpoint group IDs for
the IPSec connection (and cannot specify the peer CIDRs in the IPSec
connection API).

Implication here is that the subnet will be an optional argument for
the VPN service API.

With this feature, when an endpoint group is deleted, a check is made
to ensure that there are no IPSec connections using the group.

Migration will move the subnet from VPN service API to a new endpoint
group, and specify the group in any connections using the service.
The peer CIDR(s) will be moved from each connection to an endpoint
group, with the group ID specified in the connection.

Note: As part of testing the database methods for this feature, several
more tests were created to test database access only, instead of doing
a round trip test. In a separate commit, these tests can be expanded,
and the existing round trip tests removed.

Note: Tests for building the dict used in sync requests was enhanced,
as part of supporting this feature. The previous tests didn't check
that the peer CIDR information was correct, so were enhanced as well.

Note: The service driver passes the local CIDR(s) in a new field,
called local_cidrs. This field is used for the older API, as well,
passing the subnet's CIDR, and allowing consistent consumption by the
device driver. The IP version is also passed, rather than obtaining
it from the subnet info (so both new and old API use the same fields).

Note: to support rolling upgrades, where an agent may be using the older
release, after the server has been updated, the subnet CIDR field passed
from the service driver to device driver, will be populated from the
first local endpoint from the first connection (there has to be at least
one connection, when sending data to the agent).

Note: In the device driver, I noticed that the local CIDR's IP version
can change the config file output, so I added test cases for IPv6, as
part of enhancing the tests for multiple local CIDRs.

Change-Id: I7a011e3170d7db463a6561e550b2ead3e3311125
Partial-Bug: 1459423

vpnservice_id) validator.validate_ipsec_conn_optional_args(ipsec_sitecon, vpnservice.subnet) if ipsec_sitecon['local_ep_group_id']: self.get_endpoint_info(context, ipsec_sitecon) ip_version = None else: ip_version = vpnservice.subnet.ip_version validator.validate_ipsec_site_connection(context, ipsec_sitecon, ip_version, vpnservice) status=p_constants.PENDING_CREATE, commit_message:
Fix infinite spinner for Angular panels

Allow Angular panels to refresh when URI and the
link location is the same.

The solution is based off comments at

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16002984/angularjs-how-can-i-do-a-redirect-with-a-full-page-load

Closes Bug: #1506211

Change-Id: Icb4f3fba8386eea90c782db65e8b3a62f649a1e8

commit_message:
Don't hide Karma coverage reports

This patch updates the file names of the coverage reports so they are
visible by default on most systems. Also updates the .gitignore, so the
new files are not pushed to the Horizon repo.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: 1508526
Change-Id: I3c1c8f4c88819e2f49b60722ea8cc37bdc711b8c

Add new endpoint to health service API

This commit makes the endpoint '/runs/metadata/keys' available to
our JavaScript application.

commit_message:
Updated(into the Github repository) the added  filter to secret list for acl secrets.

In the previous commit the author added a neat feature to allow users
to get a list of secrets for which they are on the ACL.
This has been updated to the respective places.

Change-Id: Ic05400e5b81daacb47d6ceadadd99283b581037e
Closes-Bug: #1499324
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/48/240348/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_list_secrets_with_no_acls_and_acl_only_should_be_empty(self): """Return list should be empty""" creator_user_id = 'creatorUserID' self._create_secret_with_creator_user( self.app, creator_user_id) resp = self.app.get( '/secrets/?acl_only=TRUE') self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_int) self.assertEqual([], resp.json['secrets']) def test_list_secrets_with_acls(self): """Return List should not include secrets with no ACL for user""" creator_user_id = 'creatorUserID' secret_uuid_acl_1 = self._create_secret_with_creator_user( self.app, creator_user_id) secret_uuid_acl_2 = self._create_secret_with_creator_user( self.app, creator_user_id) secret_uuid_no_acl = self._create_secret_with_creator_user( self.app, creator_user_id) create_acls( self.app, 'secrets', secret_uuid_acl_1, read_user_ids=[creator_user_id], read_project_access=False) create_acls( self.app, 'secrets', secret_uuid_acl_2, read_user_ids=[creator_user_id], read_project_access=False) resp = self.app.get( '/secrets/?acl_only=TrUe') self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_int) secret_list = resp.json.get('secrets') self.assertEqual(len(secret_list), 2) self.assertNotIn(secret_uuid_no_acl, secret_list)

commit_message:
Add unit tests around HomeController

As part of building a reliable UI, I am including tests around our
core components.

There is a minor change made to HomeController: instead of getting the
current date as part of the loading process, the date is injected once
the controller is loaded. That helps us testing the controller behavior.

Change-Id: Id19bc9e212329990a415077f53924321ce737bed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/90/238490/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function HomeController($scope, healthService) { vm.processData = processData; vm.loadData = loadData; vm.chartData = []; vm.chartDataRate = []; vm.projects = []; function processData(data) { vm.chartData.push({ key: 'Passes', values: passEntries, color: "blue" }); vm.chartData.push({ key: 'Failures', values: failEntries, color: "red" }); vm.chartDataRate.push({ key: '% Failures', values: failRateEntries }); Object.keys(projects).forEach(function(name) { vm.projects.push(projects[name]); } function loadData() { var start = $scope.currentDate || new Date(); }
deleted_lines: function HomeController(healthService) { vm.processData = function(data) { vm.chartData = [ { key: 'Passes', values: passEntries, color: "blue" }, { key: 'Failures', values: failEntries, color: "red" } ]; vm.chartDataRate = [ { key: '% Failures', values: failRateEntries } ]; vm.projects = Object.keys(projects).map(function(name) { return projects[name]; }; vm.loadData = function() { var start = new Date(); };

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-04 02:42:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/056aa5d7fbbe00abf053936a973c68727baddf59', 'message': "Support OFFLINE mode

Previously, if the devstack user set OFFLINE=True in local.conf,
networking-ovn would ignore this and try to clone OVS from git,
which would fail if the repository wasn't already there. This
commit fixes this so if OFFLINE=True is set in local.conf, we
verify this before trying to clone OVS, and die if the OVS git
repository is not there when in OFFLINE mode.

Change-Id: Ie5439128107a42306b25be5dc5de2517977859e7
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-04 16:17:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn/commit/588f00b73f946f028343a8287bbd2362110ca21c', 'message': 'Support OFFLINE mode

commit_message:
Support OFFLINE mode

This patch makes use of the "git_clone" function, which handles
OFFLINE=True implicitly.

Change-Id: Ie5439128107a42306b25be5dc5de2517977859e7
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/47/241447/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "$OFFLINE" != "True" ]; then git clone $OVN_REPO cd $OVN_REPO_NAME else die $LINENO "Cannot clone $OVN_REPO in OFFLINE mode" fi

commit_message:
warm pip wheel cache during image build

This installs everything in upper-constraints in a throw away venv,
which has the knock on effect of fully populating the wheel cache for
root with wheels for everything. This hopefully speeds up all devstack
runs quite a bit.

Change-Id: I429f353c33d892f76552c83d34ac1329ed18f97f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/92/241692/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # Copyright (C) 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # dib-lint: disable=setpipefail if [ ${DIB_DEBUG_TRACE:-0} -gt 0 ]; then set -x fi set -eu REQUIREMENTS_DIR=/opt/git/openstack/requirements BUILDPIP_VENV=/opt/git/build_pip # Setup venv and install all of the global requirements. This will # create a warm pip cache which can be used by devstack later. sudo virtualenv $BUILDPIP_VENV sudo -H $BUILDPIP_VENV/bin/pip install -r $REQUIREMENTS_DIR/upper-constraints.txt # Delete the venv after the script, we don't care about the venv, just # the cache artifacts left around. sudo rm -rf $BUILDPIP_VENV

commit_message:
Remove references to router_delete_namespaces option in tests

Deprecated router_delete_namespaces option was removed in neutron
by change I2a879213c3b095a007a4531f430a33cea9fdf1bd and this caused
failures of functional tests.
We should remove all references to this option.

Change-Id: I80cc5bc1037c974a816466f94f354927ba21c726

commit_message:
Fix volume size units to match the API

Both Horizon and the cinder client documents the size paramater in
gigabyes(GBs) but the API docs(both v1 and v2) list the size units as
gibibytes(GiBs). The correct unit should be gibibytes(GiBs). This
should help in clearing up any confusion on what units are used in
Cinder.

Closes-bug: 1511167
Change-Id: I42e15c18d1f084d435a2be9b343fb2f6c3cf377f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/05/241405/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Honor rabbitmq username/password

If a rabbitmq username/password were set in undercloud.conf previously,
they were not honored, and all services would fail to connect to rabbit.
Also cleans up the way we include rabbit in the puppet manifest to bring
it inline with how it's done for the Overcloud.

Change-Id: If851db7edf3e2fc5fbd0722ebf3df6e5b16681a0

commit_message:
Use SEED_IP to decide if we can ssh to the undercloud

And default it to "", this will prevent a "unbound variable"
error, also don't set it until we know we should have ssh
access to the seed.

Change-Id: I4b7ce35cabed3068bd68c7519fbbd1e6e755dba5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/12/223612/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "${SEED_IP:-}" != "" ] ; then# Set SEED_IP here to prevent postci ssh'ing to the undercloud before its up and running SEED_IP=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$TE_DATAFILE os-apply-config --key seed-ip --type netaddress --key-default '')

subject: Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-22 16:06:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-trove/commit/4e0005e23357607df0d8603bcc52dd26dab6a54c', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I4b72eef7fd4d4ee7b226a5014b7d180506161f69
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-23 15:10:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-trove/commit/8a798d49acf5d701f2622c805220d16f8eefd1d0', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I4b72eef7fd4d4ee7b226a5014b7d180506161f69
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-10-27 02:41:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-trove/commit/613e2a6700d2fff58702d78a5c185af4b372001b', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross

commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Change-Id: I4b72eef7fd4d4ee7b226a5014b7d180506161f69

commit_message:
clarify the example in 'Simulation with Actions'

In RST document congress/doc/source/enforcement.rst.

The policy 'aliceactions' is created at first in the example,
but that is never used, all the following command use the
default 'action' policy, that make the users confused about
which policy we should create "action('set')" rule into and
which action policy we should use in simulate? Aims to clarify
the usage, avoid to use default 'action' policy, and use
'aliceactions' policy in the example.

Change-Id: I1c976120c20b8e766a6692d3ab16e91f92da8b5c
Closes-Bug: #1510428
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/55/239655/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ openstack congress policy rule create aliceactions 'action("set")' $ openstack congress policy rule create aliceactions 'p+(x,y) :- set(x,y)' $ openstack congress policy rule create aliceactions 'p-(x,oldy) :- set(x,y), p(x,oldy)' $ openstack congress policy simulate classification 'error(x)' 'set(101, 5)' aliceactions 'set(101, 9) set(202, 9) set(302, 1)' aliceactions --delta 'set(101, 9) set(202, 9) set(302, 1) set(101, 15)' aliceactions --delta 'set(101, 9) p+(202, 7)' aliceactions --delta
deleted_lines: $ openstack congress policy rule create action 'action("set")' $ openstack congress policy rule create action 'p+(x,y) :- set(x,y)' $ openstack congress policy rule create action 'p-(x,oldy) :- set(x,y), p(x,oldy)' $ openstack congress policy simulate classification 'error(x)' 'set(101, 5)' action 'set(101, 9) set(202, 9) set(302, 1)' action --delta 'set(101, 9) set(202, 9) set(302, 1) set(101, 15)' action --delta 'set(101, 9) p+(202, 7)' action --delta

commit_message:
Fixing bug in injection test

The injection test was broken, it assumed that the call arg in the
context would reflect the type passed into the detected call, this
is not the case. We check the AST node type instead now

Change-Id: Idd7d8ed5ab7062af79b8e77d6df0cc39bddb7663
Closes-bug: 1513091

commit_message:
Mostly revert "Disable tempest"

This reverts commit 78f7de73973d3676185348e3e22963096f1536d1 except for
the deprecation notes in undercloud.conf.sample.
Tempest is now available in delorean.

Change-Id: Ief0cef5c022a8904582eb3c71a537d3cae75fde6

commit_message:
Use RequestSpec object in HostManager

Since now there is a RequestSpec, let's use it for the HostManager.

Partially-Implements: blueprint request-spec-object-mitaka

Change-Id: Ic762c8f1f8a666bcb0e9c5aea9f4022052e89fcf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/51/191251/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def consume_from_instance(self, spec_obj): """Incrementally update host state from an RequestSpec object.""" disk_mb = (spec_obj.root_gb + spec_obj.ephemeral_gb) * 1024 ram_mb = spec_obj.memory_mb vcpus = spec_obj.vcpus pci_requests = spec_obj.pci_requests
deleted_lines: def consume_from_instance(self, instance): """Incrementally update host state from an instance.""" disk_mb = (instance['root_gb'] + instance['ephemeral_gb']) * 1024 ram_mb = instance['memory_mb'] vcpus = instance['vcpus'] pci_requests = instance.get('pci_requests')

commit_message:
run_tests: install puppet from puppetlabs.com repo

Use puppetlabs.com repositories to handle Puppet packaging, like it's
done in Beaker jobs.

That way, we will run the latest version available in Puppetlabs
repositories, in a consistent way with beaker jobs.

Depends-On: Iaba6e499b1185d75930f0e7b0ca587e9f8705e5a
Change-Id: I2d49c1e913bbbf243dca3fcf41f592168f46b57b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/40/241340/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: wget https://apt.puppetlabs.com/puppetlabs-release-trusty.deb -O /tmp/puppet.deb $SUDO dpkg -i /tmp/puppetlabs-release-trusty.deb $SUDO apt-get install -y dstat puppet facter wget https://yum.puppetlabs.com/puppetlabs-release-el-7.noarch.rpm -o /tmp/puppet.rpm $SUDO rpm -ivh /tmp/puppet.rpm $SUDO yum install -y dstat puppet facter
deleted_lines: $SUDO apt-get install -y dstat $SUDO yum install -y dstat

subject: Sets loaded rule info to Rule instances
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-21 00:36:06.000000000', 'files': ['congress/policy_engines/agnostic.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/04eb262cea276fae61b624ba00155d5027119ff0', 'message': "Sets loaded rule info to Rule instances

Policy Engine initializes Rule instances when Congress starts
if rules are persited in db. The bug is that Policy Engine only
loads persited rule string but doesn't set other infomation,
id, name and comment. This patch lets Policy Engine set the
lacked infomations to Rule instance.

Closes-Bug: #1507329
Change-Id: Id8354d9bff0d5b5938406473e2f344e726bd2f3c
(cherry picked from commit 19dd02831ec995c4bcabc256bac1b0dde5088bb5)

commit_message:
Sets loaded rule info to Rule instances

Policy Engine initializes Rule instances when Congress starts
if rules are persited in db. The bug is that Policy Engine only
loads persited rule string but doesn't set other infomation,
id, name and comment. This patch lets Policy Engine set the
lacked infomations to Rule instance.

Closes-Bug: #1507329
Change-Id: Id8354d9bff0d5b5938406473e2f344e726bd2f3c
(cherry picked from commit 19dd02831ec995c4bcabc256bac1b0dde5088bb5)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/25/237825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parsed_rule.set_id(rule.id) parsed_rule.set_name(rule.name) parsed_rule.set_comment(rule.comment) parsed_rule.set_original_str(rule.rule)

commit_message:
Use oslo_config new type PortOpt for port options

The oslo_config library provides new type PortOpt to validate the
range of port now.

Change-Id: Iecd1e35c9108bb455204d110177b00f622b77a2c
ref: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/blob/2.6.0/oslo_config/cfg.py#L1114
Depends-On: Ida294b05a85f5bef587b761fcd03c28c7a3474d8
Depends-On: Ifce070d8d85ef52524a24359335de235e91812a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/94/238394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.PortOpt('bind_port', default=1789, help="The port to bind to"),
deleted_lines: cfg.IntOpt('bind_port', default=1789, help="The port to bind to"),

commit_message:
Manage keystone initialization directly in t-h-t manifests

This is the second change of a servies of two, it creates the
user, user_role, service and endpoint for:

  * glance
  * nova
  * neutron
  * cinder
  * horizon
  * swift
  * ceilometer
  * heat

Change-Id: I50e792d98a2ba516ff498c58ad402f463c5f7e76

added_lines: glance_public_url: list_join: - '' - - {get_param: GlanceProtocol} - '://' - {get_param: GlanceApiVirtualIP} - ':' - {get_param: GlancePort} glance_admin_url: list_join: - '' - - {get_param: GlanceProtocol} - '://' - {get_param: GlanceApiVirtualIP} - ':' - {get_param: GlancePort} glance::keystone::auth::public_url: {get_input: glance_public_url } glance::keystone::auth::admin_url: {get_input: glance_admin_url } glance::keystone::auth::password: {get_input: glance_password }

commit_message:
Unretire the stackforge/compass-install repo

We retired the stackforge/compass-install repo by mistake. Restore
it now until it can be batched into a future rename maintenance.

Change-Id: If9452ffc18f7dab3347d651f17850eb1b3a63d63

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/47/236147/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Start datasource synchronizer after explicitly starting the # datasources, because the explicit call to create a datasource # will crash if the synchronizer creates the datasource first. synchronizer_path = os.path.join(src_path, "synchronizer.py") LOG.info("main::start() synchronizer: %s", synchronizer_path) cage.loadModule("Synchronizer", synchronizer_path) cage.createservice( name="synchronizer", moduleName="Synchronizer", description="DB synchronizer instance", args={'poll_time': cfg.CONF.datasource_sync_period}) synchronizer = cage.service_object('synchronizer') args={'policy_engine': engine, 'synchronizer': synchronizer})

subject: Add a script to start and monitor children processes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-07 00:48:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/393547b972e705a4704c043215a7cb1619cb377d', 'message': 'Add a script to start and monitor children processes

start_processes.py starts processes described in a config file.
start_processes.py will restarted processes that die if configured with
restart_delay.

Change-Id: I9d41ddf615627dda9c67bea6f2a59298de17e605
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-07 17:04:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/818fc6143ad187eddd78b3dd16a93a8e087f3582', 'message': 'Add a script to start and monitor children processes

start_processes.py starts processes described in a config file.
start_processes.py will restarted processes that die if configured with

commit_message:
Add a script to start and monitor children processes

start_processes.py starts processes described in a config file.
start_processes.py will restart processes that die if configured with
restart_delay.

Change-Id: I9d41ddf615627dda9c67bea6f2a59298de17e605
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/65/210165/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This script starts a number of children processes defined in a config file. # If restart_delay is not None, this will restart a crashed process after # restart_delay seconds. The config file content should look like this: # { # "datasource_drivers": # [ # { "cmd": "ls", # "args": ["-l"], # "restart_delay": 5 # }, # # { "cmd": "watch", # "args": ["ls", "-l", "/tmp"] # } # ] # } import simplejson import subprocess import time children = [] class ProcessEntry(object): def __init__(self, id, process, cmd, args, restart_delay): self.id = id self.process = process self.cmd = cmd self.args = args self.restart_delay = restart_delay self.time_of_death = None def start_process(id, cmd, args, restart_delay): out = open("stdout.%d" % id, 'w') err = open("stderr.%d" % id, 'w') print ("Starting process: " + cmd + ' ' + ' '.join(args)) p = subprocess.Popen([cmd] + args, stdout=out, stderr=err) print ("Started as pid %d" % p.pid) children.append(ProcessEntry(id, p, cmd, args, restart_delay)) def wait_all(): print "Monitoring %d children" % len(children) while(True): for c in children: c.process.poll() if c.process.returncode is not None: if c.time_of_death is None: print ("pid %d ended with return code %d" % (c.process.pid, c.process.returncode)) c.time_of_death = time.time() if c.restart_delay is not None: if c.time_of_death + c.restart_delay < time.time(): print "Restarting " + c.cmd + ' ' + ' '.join(c.args) children.remove(c) start_process(c.id, c.cmd, c.args, c.restart_delay) else: children.remove(c) if not children: break time.sleep(.1) def main(): config_file = 'sample_process_config.json' txt = open(config_file).read() config = simplejson.loads(txt) for id, driver in enumerate(config['datasource_drivers']): start_process(id, driver['cmd'], driver['args'], driver.get('restart_delay')) wait_all() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Add availability zone information into nova driver

The user can specify which AZ is used to boot up a vm. Since AZ can be
also used to separate security zones it is very useful to have this
information in Congress in order to monitor if VMs are placed in the
right network and uses the correct volume backend.

For more detail information see [1].

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/telcowg-usecases/blob/master/usecases/sec_segregation.rst

Change-Id: Ie53a0fa0600a20f478791a81e7c750378e91476b

commit_message:
Add Mitaka Priorities

As discussed at the Design Summit, we have come up with a list of
priorities for the Mitaka Release.

Change-Id: Ib46774031741cb037944c7ba04a6748a421781e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/59/240959/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: List of priorities (in the form of use cases) the nova development team is prioritizing in Liberty (in no particular order). +-------------------------+-----------------------+ | Priority | Primary Contacts | +=========================+=======================+ | `Cells V2`_ | `Andrew Laski`_ | +-------------------------+-----------------------+ | `V2.1 API`_ | `Ken'ichi Ohmichi`_, | | | `Sean Dague`_ | +-------------------------+-----------------------+ | `Scheduler`_ | `Jay Pipes`_ | +-------------------------+-----------------------+ | `OS VIF Lib + PrivSep`_ | `Daniel Berrange`_, | | | `Jay Pipes`_ | +-------------------------+-----------------------+ | `Live Migrate`_ | `Paul Murray`_ | +-------------------------+-----------------------+ .. _Andrew Laski: https://launchpad.net/~alaski .. _Ken'ichi Ohmichi: https://launchpad.net/~oomichi .. _Sean Dague: https://launchpad.net/~sdague .. _Jay Pipes: https://launchpad.net/~jaypipes .. _Daniel Berrange: https://launchpad.net/~berrange .. _Paul Murray: https://launchpad.net/~pmurray Priorities without a clear plan ------------------------------- TODO Cells v2 -------- We started the cells v2 effort in Kilo. During Mitaka are are focusing on making the default setup a single cells v2 deployment. In the N release, we hope to have support for multiple cells in a cells v2 deployment, including a way to migrate existing cells v1 deployments to cells v2. V2.1 API --------- In Liberty, by default we now enable v2.1 for all API endpoints. In Mitaka, we are going to focus on documenting the API. Scheduler --------- During Kilo we made much progress on cleaning up the interface between the scheduler and the rest of Nova. Liberty we added the request spec object. In Mitaka we hope to complete the work around request spec and resource objects. We also want to start looking at the service group API, and more work on the resource tracker. OS VIF Lib ---------- TODO Live Migrate ------------ TODO
deleted_lines: TODO: fill this in after summit

commit_message:
Add tripleo F22 periodic jobs

Run the 3 tripleo jobs daily, these can be used to test the most recent
trunk repository. Once the patch triggered ci jobs have moved to F22 we
can use these to trigger a promotion of trunk repositories used by tripleo.

Change-Id: I32d1d6684c6b13b496d082cbf17f3e71b1977879

commit_message:
Use hex strings instead of messing with bits

Replace the custom bytes_to_bin with writing the values as hex.

Change-Id: I1072f889ac9a184ba68b86f89f9c95b0294b27f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/anchor refs/changes/10/235710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def bytes_to_bin(bytes): """Convert byte string to bit string.""" return "".join([_pad_byte(_int_to_bin(_ord(byte))) for byte in bytes]) def _int_to_bin(n): if n == 0 or n == 1: return str(n) elif n % 2 == 0: return _int_to_bin(n // 2) + "0" else: return _int_to_bin(n // 2) + "1"
